discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Maybe useful info?
The ION 2000 utilizes an inline insertion method with fail-to-wire redundancy to accomplish this. The inline insertion method enables the ION device to inspect or process traffic by only requiring physical changes to the network while maintaining or enabling additional redundancy.
Src: https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/hardware/ion-2000-hardware-reference/install-ion-2000/set-up-ion-2000-with-existing-router
Agree B and D, but yes voting allows for only 1, the other options dont pertain to SD-WAN
Should be B and D, voting allows single answer only.
Choose two means choose two: should be B and D...still searching the right docu for confirmation

questions.question_text: What are two benefits of installing hardware fail-to-wire port pairs on Instant-On Network (ION) devices? (Choose two.)

choices.D: ensures automatic failover when ION devices experience software or network related failure
choices.A: local area network (LAN) Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) and DHCP relay functionality
choices.B: control mode insertion without modification of existing network configuration

questions.question_text: What are two benefits provided to an organization using a secure web gateway (SWG)? (Choose two.)

choices.A: VPNs remain connected, reducing user risk exposure.
choices.D: An encrypted challenge-response mechanism obtains user credentials from the browser.
choices.C: Access to inappropriate websites or content is blocked based on acceptable use policies.
choices.B: Security policies for making internet access safer are enforced.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Agree with yet_another_user, so BC.
Should be D. Secure traffic from user to App is CASB

comments.content: CASB can be more than just Web Based, I think that's why SWG is the answer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Should be C

Selected Answer: C
The secure web gateway (C) is a proxy (A). But I think PANW would like to hear their name --> hence it should be C.

Selected Answer: C
I think the answer is C.

discussion.content:

questions.question_text:
A company is expanding its operations to multiple cloud environments and needs seamless connectivity between their on-premises data centers and the cloud environments. They want to ensure high performance and secure connectivity without complex tunneling protocols.

Which recommendation will meet this company's needs?

choices.C: Traditional VPN tunnels with manual configuration for each cloud environment
choices.B: Dedicated MPLS lines to each cloud provider for guaranteed bandwidth
choices.A: Prisma SD-WAN's integration with AWS Cloud WAN using Tunnel-less Connect
choices.D: Prisma SD-WAN CloudEdge Connector for dynamic traffic routing
